sections.title: Healthcare Planning for Retirement
sections.subtitle: Understanding Medicare, supplemental insurance, and long-term care

sections.title: Medicare Basics
sections.content: Medicare is the federal health insurance program for people 65 and older. It consists of Part A (hospital insurance), Part B (medical insurance), Part C (Medicare Advantage), and Part D (prescription drug coverage). Enrollment typically begins 3 months before your 65th birthday.

points.title: Part A
points.description: Hospital stays, skilled nursing care, hospice - premium-free for most people.

points.title: Part B
points.description: Doctor visits, outpatient care, preventive services - monthly premium required.

points.title: Part D
points.description: Prescription drug coverage through private insurance companies.

sections.title: Enrollment Timing Matters
sections.content: You have a 7-month initial enrollment period around your 65th birthday. Missing this can result in late enrollment penalties and gaps in coverage.

sections.title: Supplemental Insurance Options
sections.content: Medicare doesn't cover everything, so most people need supplemental coverage. Medigap policies fill gaps in Original Medicare, while Medicare Advantage plans provide all-in-one coverage through private insurers. Long-term care insurance covers extended care needs that Medicare doesn't cover.

sections.title: Plan Your Healthcare Coverage
steps: Research Medicare options 6-12 months before turning 65
Compare Medigap policies or Medicare Advantage plans in your area
Consider long-term care insurance if you have significant assets to protect
Estimate your healthcare costs and include them in your retirement budget

sections.title: Healthcare Costs Rise with Age
sections.content: Healthcare expenses typically increase significantly after age 70. Plan for these costs to avoid depleting your retirement savings on medical care.
